nodes.text: Major infrastructure investment systematically results in the worst projects being built because promoters and decision processes favor projects that look best on biased forecasts, a phenomenon described as "survival of the un-fittest"

Major infrastructure projects have characteristics that make them inherently risky: long planning horizons, complex interfaces, non-standard technology, multi-actor decision making, scope changes, lock-in, and inadequate contingencies

Empirical evidence from 258 transportation projects across 20 nations shows large cost overruns: average rail 44.7% (SD 38.4), bridges/tunnels 33.8% (SD 62.4), roads 20.4% (SD 29.9); 9 out of 10 projects have overruns and overruns persist over 70 years

Empirical evidence on demand forecasts (208 projects) shows large benefit shortfalls: rail actual passengers on average 51.4% lower than forecast (i.e. forecasts overestimated by 105.6%), 9 out of 10 rail forecasts overestimate; road forecasts are less biased but still inaccurate
Conventional ex ante cost-benefit analysis for major projects is unreliable and biased because it uses systematically underestimated costs and overestimated benefits

Combined empirical effects make CBAs misleading: e.g., average rail cost overrun combined with average traffic shortfall produces large negative ex-post economic outcomes; Channel Tunnel and Great Belt examples show severe cost overruns, revenue shortfalls, and negative or non-viable returns
Three classes of explanations exist for forecasting inaccuracy: technical error, psychological optimism bias (planning fallacy), and political-economic strategic misrepresentation

Large-sample data reject technical explanations as primary causes: forecasting errors are systematically biased (means differ from zero) and have not improved over decades despite methodological investments

Psychological explanations (optimism bias) can account for some inaccuracy but are insufficient as a primary, sole explanation because professional forecasting has not learned away the bias over decades and forecasters rarely cite optimism bias as main cause

Political-economic explanations of strategic misrepresentation best account for the systematic underestimation of costs and overestimation of benefits: promoters and planners have rational incentives to bias forecasts to secure funding, producing inverted Darwinism where projects that look best on paper but are worst in reality get built

Interview and case evidence (UK and US studies) show that planners, politicians, local interests, and consultants face incentives to emphasize benefits and hide true costs and risks; consultants often justify projects under client pressure, and actors knowingly withhold adverse cost information to secure funding

Reference class forecasting (the outside view) is a methodological remedy: identify a relevant reference class of past projects, establish a probability distribution of outcomes for that class, and compare the current project to that distribution to adjust forecasts

Reference class forecasting has produced improved estimates in practice (e.g., Edinburgh Tram cost uplift from 320m to 400m for 80% certainty); the method has been endorsed and used by governments and professional bodies internationally

Governance reforms are required to change incentives: increase transparency and public accountability, independent peer review and benchmarking, shift appraisal to neutral bodies, enforce professional and legal penalties, and use market controls such as private finance sharing risk

Specific governance measures recommended and observed: block grants instead of categorical grants, independent audits and benchmarking (including reference class), public disclosure and hearings, contingent private financing without sovereign guarantees for a significant share, and shared financial responsibility for forecast errors

Conclusion: current trends—large stimulus spending, rapid shift of projects to emerging economies, and increased ICT content—amplify risks of cost overruns and benefit shortfalls; combining outside-view methods with stronger governance is necessary to avoid large financial and economic disasters
